data.title: Rebranding The Infatuation: A Company With a Passionate Audience & 7 Years of History
data.meta_description: Here at The Infatuation, we help people find their way to the best meals in an approachable, funny, opinionated, and not-taking-ourselves-too-seriously manner. We‚Äôre like Zagat for a new generation‚Ä¶
data.text:
Here at The Infatuation, we help people find their way to the best meals in an approachable, funny, opinionated, and not-taking-ourselves-too-seriously manner. We‚Äôre like Zagat for a new generation. You‚Äôll never find us using words like ‚Äòtoothsome‚Äô our ‚Äòmouthfeel‚Äô to describe a piece of meat, but you will find over 1.6k unbiased reviews on the best restaurants around through our Website, our iPhone & Android apps, and Text Rex.

Chris Stang, co-founder & CEO of The Infatuation brought me in to help centralize all our creative under one umbrella. We‚Äôre a small company with a large audience, and we think branding is one of the most important things for us to focus on. We think critically, down to the smallest details. We provide information to an audience that craves authenticity and opinionated info on restaurant experiences.

This article covers the overall process we followed while rebranding. The point is to provide an inside look at how we settled on some of these decisions. Every company is different‚Äîthis process worked for us and fluidly evolved through the duration of the rebrand. If you‚Äôre working on a rebrand, hopefully some of this info can help with your process.

Anatomy of our logo

Above is the redesigned logo. Below, we‚Äôll cover the process we took to arrive at that conclusion. If you need to take a restroom break you should probably do it now, because this is a long one, and you‚Äôre going to be sucked into the beauty that awaits. BUCKLE UP.

Getting to the core of what we do

When we initially started working on this project, we made an effort to really simplify what we stand for, and what we provide to our users. People access our content in many different ways including:

Restaurant reviews and guides on theinfatuation.com.

Email newsletters spanning across 7 cities.

Text Rex: SMS service connecting users to expert humans who help you figure out where to eat (beta).

iOS and Android apps.

Social: Instagram, Snapchat, Facebook, and Twitter.

This is quite a large range of services considering The Infatuation used to be a blog run by Chris and Andrew as a passion project showing their love for good food and disdain for esoteric restaurant reviews.

Keeping all our platforms in mind, we began to think about our positioning as a company. We discovered a common goal with all of these parts‚Äîthey all help you decide where to go eat a meal.

After seeing everything holistically up on a whiteboard ‚Äî a magic moment struck. We came to the realization that we tend to make up words for things, so, for example:

Experiences = #EEEEEATS (our popular hastag on instagram with over 3.5 million posts).

Recommendations = Rex (following Text Rex, our SMS recommendation service we created in June of 2015).

Decisions = ???

We needed a special word for decisions, since all of our services have a goal of enabling you to make a decision, or even deciding for you. Many suggestions where thrown around until we reached another magic moment and coined ourselves as:

The Infatuation: Your Restaurant Decider

With this identification, the rebrand process became quite a bit easier. Every decision we make fits within the context of our core brand offering of helping you figure out where to go experience a meal. Basically: the main problem we‚Äôre trying to solve has to do with why the name of this restaurant is funny and relatable:

Strategizing a logo that can represent us as Deciders.

Time to begin designing the logo. So, open illustrator right? Not quite yet. We took a couple time-saving steps to help suss out the strategy of where we want this thing to land.

Survey, survey survey.

To start out, I sent around a survey to the team getting their views on the current Infatuation landscape. This was great input to see where everyone is at mentally, which is to say, WEIRD. To be clear, this is input that can help inform the decision, but it should by no means solely drive the decisions. Here are the questions that were asked of the team to really pin down how everyone was feeling about the brand:

In your mind, what word best describes The Infatuation?

What do you like about the current logo? What does it do well to communicate the brand?

What do you dislike about the current logo? What are the ways it improperly communicates what we do?

What does The Infatuation provide that other companies in the space can‚Äôt?

If The Infatuation was a restaurant, which one would it be & why?

What do our users love most about us?

Do you like Pizza?

17/17 Infatuation folks confirmed that they like pizza. That‚Äôs huge news for the team party planning committee.

Distilling information into a creative brief

With these survey results and through additional conversations, we came up with a creative brief that captured where we wanted the brand to head. I followed an approach learned from Frank Harris that he picked up during his Etsy days. Using this process, we asked ourselves 3 simple questions:

What problems does the current logo have?

What does the current logo communicate that we want to keep?

What objectives do we have for the mark and what are some possible solutions?

This ensures we keep what we like from the current mark while pushing the branding to the next level. Here‚Äôs a link to the full design brief.

Analyzing the competition

It‚Äôs also important to identify where we sit within the context of our competitors. We drew a couple charts and scenarios to really get a sense of who our competitors are from a primary, secondary, and tertiary perspective. Hint: It‚Äôs mostly Domino‚Äôs Pizza.

Next, we pulled all the information gathered in the strategy stage and started getting visual. We put up a lot of info. Visual styles that could work well for the brand. Things we personally like. Photos that represent our attitude. We then reacted to each piece with sticky notes. Green for good things, blue for neutral things, and red for bad things. This exercise can only be done effectively when everything is actually printed out for everyone to see. Connections are easier to make when looking at everything holistically‚Äîthis is harder to do when paging through a PDF on screen.

I found it easiest to create sub mood-boards based on our ideas as well. At one point, we thought maybe the combination of a mouth and a compass could be good to help represent our penchant for good EEEEEATS and restaurant discovery. For that, we made a mouth-board.

We also wanted to find out a rough brand archetype to help steer the creative. Gathering images around this helped pinpoint a rough direction to pursue. In looking at the ‚ÄúBrand Archetypes‚Äù chart, we ultimately decided the Outlaw feel fits us well. We do things differently than other publications reviewing restaurants, and we‚Äôre certainly not taking cues from the elder statesmen of the industry. We do what makes sense to us and what‚Äôs best for our users and readers ‚Äî at all costs. We create the unexpected (see the unconventionally branded sony tea pot in the image above), we aim to be witty, but not wacky (see Dave Chapelle), we‚Äôre laid back (like The Dude, but less lazy).

Getting Sketchy

Once the moodboard was roughly set and we were able to react to everything, I dove in with a bunch of different sketches and ideas based on the requirements gathered in the information and exploration phases.

Basically, this is kind of a stream of consciousness on a page to see if any ideas stuck. Really quick sketches ‚Äî nothing polished (or even good for that matter). It‚Äôs more to capture the idea, then bring that idea into illustrator for further refinement.

After pinning some of these ideas up, as a team, we started to unpack the word ‚ÄúInfatuation‚Äù and all the feeling and action that comes with it. Infatuation defined is:

An intense but short-lived passion or admiration for someone or something.

It‚Äôs not really love, it‚Äôs more like short-lived, intense, obsessive, almost unhealthy love. It‚Äôs writing your crush‚Äôs name in a notebook over and over again and maybe carving their likeness into a block of cheese. It‚Äôs clearing your mind of everything except for the one thing you‚Äôre infatuated with.

The thought of some combination of a heart and a lighting bolt started to make sense, and seemed to represent this word well. Our hearts jumping from one place to the next, just like our obsession for new restaurants and experiences. The idea was slick and on-brand. We rolled with it.

After mockup work, iteration, and perfecting the form, the BoltingHeart was born.

False Positives

Some people felt good about the BoltingHeart, others didn‚Äôt. We grabbed the whole team and gathered around a wall of BoltingHeart to see what the branding felt like as a whole. Logically, everything seemed to be there. But we were missing something. It wasn‚Äôt really tangible, it was more of a feel. The mark was too serious.

Although the BoltingHeart represented the word Infatuation very well, it didn‚Äôt represent who we are as a company. Many positives came from this false positive. It further informed where we needed to head and as a bonus we landed on a wordmark that REALLY felt like us.

Figuring out that feel‚Äîwhat were we missing?

Back to the moodboard‚Äîwe needed to identify why were missing that humorous and carefree feel. I grabbed a bunch of illustrations and icons with the green, positive post-its on them and locked them up next to our wordmark just for kicks. The results were surprising.

Using the wordmark as the visual anchor, we found out that some icons we thought were really great for the brand didn‚Äôt work at all, and we were surprised to see ones we didn‚Äôt think could work feeling really great next to the wordmark.

We settled on the vibe of the space helmet and the grey flag & shield providing the best ‚Äòfeels‚Äô for our brand.

Getting there

After figuring out the overall feel we started thinking about this idea of everyday pretentious kitchen items being somehow pulled down from their pedestals. Could we do something funny with a whisk? What about a mandoline? How can we mix this high-brow low-brow together and create an approachable mark? What‚Äôs some ridiculous combinations we can make with food / kitchen items and really pump up the humor in the mark? We had this idea around a megaphone and a ham combined, which seemed pretty stupid, so we went with it üòâ. Back to the moodboard and sketching ‚Äî started landing on a couple more ham horn ideas, along with pretentious kitchen items.

After some rough sketches to get the overall feel right, I pulled up Illustrator to create a couple more visual styles and mockups. The handle was probably the trickiest part. If positioned a certain way, it can start to feel very aggressive, and more like a cannon or a gun. NO BUENO. Other handle treatments just felt kind of wonky too.

At this point, it was in a good place to show the team and get their thoughts before diving deep into the details. I put together a quick keynote showing the mark and some possible treatments and presented it. Laughter, smiles, and comments on how ridiculous it was were plenty. THIS IS IT. It felt good to finally land on something that our team felt represented us well.

With buy-in from the team, it was now time to start working on some of the smaller details, and ham-hornifying the rest of the brand identity.

Selecting color

We knew we wanted a blue, but the blue we were using in the past didn‚Äôt feel quite right. Plus, #80b6fd is a little washed out when used on white, and not accessible to the visually impaired.

We decided to use blue instead of the typical red most food companies use. Plus, the color blue enhances trust‚ÄîIT‚ÄôS SCIENCE. Trust is important when we‚Äôre sharing our opinion on many restaurants.

Going Blue Hunting

After sitting at my computer and using the hue selector for about 19 hrs, I thought it would be nice to get out and physically go look at blue colors that could match our vision.

I went and walked around East Williamsburg (the real East Williamsburg not to be confused with Bushwick, just so we‚Äôre clear) to grab some reference shots on what could fit us the best. Here‚Äôs some of what was captured:

Getting Feedback from Creatives

Feeling good about how the kit of brand parts was coming together, it was time to start getting validation from other creatives in the field to make sure all improvements that could be made were made. When working on a mark, it‚Äôs easy to get tunnel vision and easily miss things other creative folks can see instantly. Since we don‚Äôt have a large design team at The Infatuation yet, I reached out to external sources.

Creative Friends

I ran mockups by a bunch of creative friends and colleagues that I‚Äôve worked with in the past. Big thanks to Sayaka Sugimura, Jason Strong, Shawn Hoglund, Sasha Tsimbler, Alex Osorio, and Cassie Broeckert for helping make things better. From the overarching brand positioning all the way down to the kerning on the tagline, all the feedback has been instrumental in finalizing the mark.

Inspect

Bryn Jackson runs a weekly design critique called Inspect where he brings on talented designers and illustrators to take a look at and critique work. This was instrumental to pushing the work further into the goodness zone. Guests Vicki Tan and Ryan Putnam, as well as everyone participating in Inspect were super helpful in identifying how our logo and icon system could be improved.

Executing

So now, the Ham Horn is born and the overall brand vision is set, here‚Äôs how it‚Äôs played out in our executions so far. Seeing everything here is a good baseline, and it will be great to see how these executions evolve over time.
